msContents.summary:
The only inventory of a music society in an independent volume, as far as it is known today (2012), is the inventory of the Berne Collegium musicum, started in 1761. We do not know the circumstances that led to its compilation. It was completed, or updated, in 1763 by Cantor Emanuel Wyss, who signed the book as a token of his taking over the responsibility for the belongings of the Collegium musicum. The entry for eight vocal scores of Graun's 'Tod Jesu', printed in 1785, gives us a terminus post quem for the later entries in the inventory. The frequent star signs (*) preceding the inventory entries served to check the items still present when a revision of the whole library was made, at an unknown time in the late eighteenth century.
It is not clear if the Collegium musicum of the 1760s was a direct continuation of one of the two Collegia of the late seventeenth century, called 'collegium musicum maius' and 'minus', founded by Johann Ulrich Sultzberger in 1672 and 1675 respectively, or if the two merged in the early eighteenth century. The first was made up of well-to-do citizens, the second of students and schoolboys. In any case, music-making received substantial encouragement from the town government: in 1703 a music room was furnished with an organ in the French church, where the Collegium still met in 1761.
